title: NRLW 2019: NRLW star Ali Brigginshaw back Israel Folau rugby league return, Tonga
text:
NRLW: Brisbane Broncos captain Ali Brigginshaw says players moving between clubs is just the way things are.

Brigginshaw: That's how it is

Brisbane Broncos NRLW skipper Ali Brigginshaw has backed Israel Folau’s return to rugby league.

The 31-year-old Queensland captain is in a same-sex relationship with her long-time partner Kate Daly but Brigginshaw said she does believe that Folau shouldn’t be blocked from a return to the sport.

Folau has been in sporting limbo after his now infamous April social media posts which said “hell” awaited “drunks, homosexuals, adulterers” and others unless they repented.

It saw his contract with Rugby Australia worth a reported $4 million over four years terminated and the parties enter into prolonged court proceedings which are set to continue with mediation meetings in December.

Recent court documents revealed Folau had offered to apologise for his homophobic Instagram post and conceded it could have been harmful for young gay people.

Last month, Folau looked like he had grabbed a rugby league lifeline with the Tongan national team in the Oceania Cup but the NRL flexed it’s international strength to block his return to the sport.

The NRL and ARL Commission have also been adamant Folau shouldn’t return to the game after delivering his opinion on social media.

Speaking to Hit105’s Stav, Abby and Matt in Brisbane on Friday, Brigginshaw said she doesn’t think it should stop Folau from playing.

“It’s his opinion. I just wish he didn’t share it on social media,” Brigginshaw said on air.

“If he is allowed back into it I think he doesn’t need to voice his opinions there.”

“I think he’s an amazing player and it’s disappointing that he wrote that … but I don’t think he should be disadvantaged from playing.”

Brigginshaw is open about her relationship with Daly and the pair famously shared a kiss after the NRLW star led her side to the inaugural NRLW premiership last year.

“I’ve never been one to hide my affection,” Brigginshaw said at the time.

“She’s the person I love … I have her here and I’m not going to say, ‘I can’t show you affection at the game’.

“Kate is the reason why I train hard; my family is a reason I train hard, and I go up and give them a big hug and a kiss and that doesn’t mean any different to when I go up and give her a kiss.”

But asked about how she uses social media, Brigginshaw admitted she was selective about what she posted.

“Life’s different now and everyone’s out there to find the negative so I’m definitely very cautious about what I post,” she said.

“But then I also won’t hide my life from social media just for some people. I’m pretty open that I’m in a same-sex relationship and I’m happy and that’s how it is.

“You would always kiss your partner after a game. All the boys do it so I don’t understand why us girls can’t do it.”

While the Broncos have lost just one game in the two-year history of the NRLW, Brigginshaw has tried to shift expectation for her team to the Dragons, despite being the reigning premiers and minor premiers.

Brigginshaw denied any ill-feeling to the Dragons after the five players — including star hooker Brittany Brealey — all left in the off-season.

But she wanted payback on the likes of NSW captain Kezie Apps, after the Dragons skipper had also led the Blues to Origin success against her this year.

“I still feel that loss from NSW,” Brigginshaw said.

“There is a big rivalry between the Dragons and Broncos and it has that Queensland-NSW feel.

“Kezie is the captain of NSW and I’m the captain of Queensland. And I want that win more than anything.”

— with AAP
description: Brisbane Broncos NRLW skipper Ali Brigginshaw has backed Israel Folau’s return to rugby league.
